info.game_comments:
2001 International Championship final game 1.
From the Las Vegas Hilton.

(1, 1).clue: In August 1982 Svetlana Savitskaya became the second woman to be sent here by Russia

(2, 1).clue: Her relative Sydney Kidman was a cattle baron who owned huge swaths of outback

(3, 1).clue: This world-famous blue gem is named for one of its former owners, Henry Philip Hope

(4, 1).clue: In 2000 marathon winner Naoko Takahashi became the first woman from this country to win a gold in track & field

(5, 1).clue: Found in warm & temperate zones, there are about 30 distinct species of this critter seen here

(6, 1).clue: It was once believed that the rising of this river was caused by the tears of the goddess Isis

(1, 2).clue: He took his ship, the Calypso, up the Amazon on a research expedition

(2, 2).clue: Toshiro Mifune & this director with whom he made 16 films died less than a year apart

(3, 2).clue: Bracelets worn around these joints are in style again, perhaps because they show off shapely legs

(4, 2).clue: The platform in this event is 10 meters or 33 feet above the water

(5, 2).clue: This large pack animal of South America was domesticated from the guanaco

(6, 2).clue: The Indus starts in these mountains

(1, 3).clue: This national American newspaper made its debut September 15, 1982

(2, 3).clue: This British veteran's films include "Tom Jones", "Under the Volcano" & "Erin Brockovich"

(3, 3).clue: Tiffany sells a collection of jewelry made to look like this woody grass consumed by pandas

(4, 3).clue: The first female figure skater since Sonja Henie to repeat as Olympic champion was this German in 1988

(5, 3).clue: The "giant" variety of this animal can have a hundred teeth, more than most mammals

(6, 3).clue: The Morava in Moravia empties into this river, one of Europe's chief waterways

(1, 4).clue: This English king's flagship, the Mary Rose, was raised after spending almost 450 years on the ocean floor

(2, 4).clue: This blonde beauty from South Africa gained notice when she grappled with Teri Hatcher in "2 Days in the Valley"

(3, 4).clue: Portraits of Queen Elizabeth I show that she wore necklaces of these mollusk gems

(4, 4).clue: The opening ceremony for the 1994 Winter Olympics in this city was conducted by King Harald V

(5, 4).clue: This troop member seen here is one of the most colorful of primates

(6, 4).clue: The papal palace in Avignon overlooks this river

(1, 5).clue: Freddie was unready: this transatlantic low-cost airline he created in 1977 folded its wings in 1982

(2, 5).clue: Seen here, she was born in Paris & starred in "An American Werewolf in Paris"

(3, 5).clue: This October birthstone often has a white background but displays a rainbow of colors in bright light

(4, 5).clue: At the opening of the 1952 Helsinki games, this winner of 9 gold medals carried the torch into the main stadium

(5, 5).clue: Due to a decrease in prairie dog populations, the black-footed variety of this swift weasel is now endangered

(6, 5).clue: In 1966 this river caused major damage when it flooded Florence

(1, 1).clue: It's the only element that weighs less than helium

(2, 1).clue: During WWII the VOA was in the Office of War Information; after the war it became part of this cabinet dept.

(3, 1).clue: In the 1930s the Brownshirts were Nazi thugs; Mussolini's Fascist goons were called this

(5, 1).clue: This musical instrument was derived from the lute in the early 18th century

(6, 1).clue: A ride through the history of this type of liquor is a fun-filled attraction near Edinburgh Castle

(1, 2).clue: This element was named for Marie & Pierre

(2, 2).clue: I love the online VOA pronounciation guide when we mention this country's new president Vojislav Kostunica

(3, 2).clue: In 338 B.C., under this king, Macedonia defeated the Greeks in the Battle of Chaeronea

(5, 2).clue: The trees that produce this tropical edible seen here can grow over 50 feet high

(6, 2).clue: In 2000 a new Chinese-themed area, with terra-cotta warriors, opened in this Copenhagen amusement park

(1, 3).clue: Symbolized Ar, this noble gas is used to fill most household light bulbs

(2, 3).clue: In early 2000, just before elections, this country's government began jamming VOA Farsi broadcasts

(3, 3).clue: In 1990 he won a runoff election against Stanislaw Tyminski to win the presidency of Poland

(5, 3).clue: 1 of the 2 Asian capital cities whose names start with "man"

(6, 3).clue: If you want to walk across the Bridge Over the River Kwai, head for Kanchanaburi in this country

(1, 4).clue: To make element 104, scientists in Berkeley bombarded this home state element, No. 98, with carbon, No. 6

(2, 4).clue: The first VOA broadcast, on February 24, 1942, was in this European language

(3, 4).clue: With few interrruptions, this family ruled the Holy Roman Empire for almost 400 years, from 1438-1806

(5, 4).clue: A relative of the dugong, it's also known as a sea cow

(6, 4).clue: The country known as this island "& Tobago" claims that its Carnaval is "The Greatest Show on Earth"

(1, 5).clue: It was used as a cleanser, bleach & medicine before it was used in gunpowder

(2, 5).clue: Come, Mr. Taliban, listen to the following Pashto broadcast aimed at this country

(3, 5).clue: In the 1090s this Croat capital became the seat of a Roman Catholic bishopric

(5, 5).clue: It's the easternmost of Canada's 3 Prairie Provinces

(6, 5).clue: Visit this Catalonian city to see the magnificent Guell Palace designed by Antonio Gaudi

(0, 0).clue: It's the point in the center of the circle in the U.N. emblem
